definition: in good health
of high quality; good
used to tell somebody that an action, a suggestion or a decision is acceptable
used to say you are satisfied with something
bright and not raining
pleasant to look at
made of very small grains
attractive and small or thin
very thin or narrow; made of very thin or narrow wires or threads
difficult to see or describe
that you have a lot of respect for
sounding important and impressive but unlikely to have any effect
containing only a particular metal and no other substances that reduce the quality
people say chance would be a fine thing to show that they would like to do or have the thing that somebody has mentioned, but that they do not think that it is very likely
the more complicated or detailed aspects of something
healthy; in good condition
used to emphasize something that is expressed clearly and directly, especially a criticism
to be in a difficult or dangerous situation where you could easily make a mistake
the flames, light and heat, and often smoke, that are produced when something burns
flames that are out of control and destroy buildings, trees, etc.
a pile of burning fuel, such as wood or coal, used for cooking food or heating a room
a piece of equipment for heating a room
shots from guns
strong criticism
very strong emotion, especially anger or enthusiasm
a person who is full of energy and enthusiasm
a difficult introduction to a new job or activity
to make somebody direct their anger, criticism, etc. at you, so that others do not have to face it
to use similar methods in a fight or an argument to those your opponent is using
a very strong desire to achieve something
to become friends quickly and have a very friendly relationship
to delay or be delayed in taking action
to be involved in several activities or areas of business at the same time, hoping that at least one will be successful
if something bad is being said about somebody/something, it usually has some truth in it
giving you a painful burning feeling
to be doing really well at something
from a bad situation to one that is worse
to act in a way that is not sensible and take dangerous risks
to be very successful and admired by other people
the action of firing guns
the action of forcing somebody to leave their job
a business or company
a part of the sea or a river where fish are caught in large quantities
a place where fish are bred (= kept in order to produce young) as a business
a creature that lives in water, breathes through gills, and uses fins and a tail for swimming
the soft part of fish that is eaten as food
used to emphasize how easy it is to do something
an important person (in a small community)
a person who seems unfriendly and without strong emotions
a completely different situation or person from the one previously mentioned
to drink a lot of alcohol regularly
a person who feels uncomfortable because they are in an environment that is not familiar
to have more important or more interesting things to do
neither one thing nor another
a person who is slightly strange or crazy
used to comfort somebody whose romantic relationship has ended by saying that there are many other people with whom they may have a successful relationship in the future
the sport or business of catching fish
a very small jumping insect without wings, that bites animals and humans and drinks their blood
if somebody sends a person away with a flea in their ear, they tell them angrily to go away
a large amount of water covering an area that is usually dry
a very large number of things or people that appear at the same time
the great flood that covered the world in the Bible story
large amounts of water covering an area that is usually dry; the fact of this happening
the process of selling shares in a company to the public for the first time in order to raise money
the act of floating on or in water
the steady and continuous movement of something/somebody in one direction
the continuous production or supply of something
continuous talk by somebody
the way that words, ideas or themes are linked together in speech, writing or music
the movement of the sea towards the land
the repeated, often regular, movement from one state to another; the repeated change in level, numbers or amount
to be relaxed and not worry about what you should do
the coloured part of a plant from which the seed or fruit develops. Flowers usually grow at the end of a stem and last only a short time.
a plant grown or valued for the beauty of its flowers
a flower with its stem that has been picked as a decoration
the finest or best part of something
the practice of adding fluoride to drinking water to prevent tooth decay (= damage from natural causes or lack of care)
a chemical element. Fluorine is a poisonous pale yellow gas and is very reactive.
food for horses and farm animals
people or things that are considered to have only one use
a thick cloud of very small drops of water in the air close to the land or sea that is very difficult to see through
a state in which things are not clear and seem difficult to understand
a cloud of very small drops of water in the air just above the ground, that make it difficult to see
a fine spray of liquid, for example from an aerosol can
the leaves of a tree or plant; leaves and branches together
things that people or animals eat
an idea that makes you think seriously and carefully
not wanting to eat anything
any substance that is used as food
a path that is made for people to walk along, especially in the country
a flat part at the side of a road for people to walk on; a pavement
a statement about what will happen in the future, based on information that is available now
a large area of land that is thickly covered with trees
a mass of tall narrow objects that are close together
to not see or understand the main point about something, because you are paying too much attention to small details
the science or practice of planting and taking care of trees and forests
the parts of a dead animal or a plant that have become hard and turned into rock
an old person, especially one who is unable to accept new ideas or adapt to changes
living in water that is not the sea and does not contain salt
having water that does not contain salt
a small animal with smooth skin, that lives both on land and in water (= is an amphibian). Frogs have very long back legs for jumping, and no tail.
an offensive word for a French person
to lose your voice or be unable to speak clearly for a short time
a weather condition in which the temperature drops below 0° Celsius (= freezing point) so that a thin white layer of ice forms on the ground and other surfaces, especially at night
the thin white layer of ice that forms when the temperature drops below 0° Celsius
the part of a plant that consists of one or more seeds and a soft inner part, can be eaten as food and usually tastes sweet
a part of a plant or tree that is formed after the flowers have died and in which seeds develop
all the natural things that the earth produces
an offensive word for a gay man
to have a successful result
a thing that is not allowed and that therefore seems very attractive
the good results of an activity or a situation
any material that produces heat or power, usually when it is burnt
a thing that is said or done that makes something, especially an argument, continue or get worse
to be very angry about something
to produce smoke or fumes
the use of special chemicals, smoke or gas to destroy the harmful insects or bacteria in a place
an organism (= a living thing) that is similar to a plant without leaves, flowers or green colouring, and that usually grows on plants or on decaying matter. mushrooms and mildew are both fungi.
a layer of mould or a similar fungus, for example on a plant or wall; an infection caused by a fungus
a substance that kills fungus
the soft thick mass of hair that grows on the body of some animals
the skin of an animal with the fur still on it, used especially for making clothes
an artificial material that looks and feels like fur
a piece of clothing, especially a coat or jacket, made of real or artificial fur
a hard grey-white substance that is sometimes left inside water pipes and containers for heating water
a grey-white layer that forms on a person’s tongue, especially when they are ill
a space surrounded on all sides by walls and a roof for heating metal or glass to very high temperatures
a container in which water is heated to provide hot water and heating in a building or to produce steam in an engine
